Posts.Content: For the last 3 or 4 weeks I've had a painful hip - right over my hip bone, hurting when I put weight on that leg and made much worse by running (only for the bus, nothing too athletic!). It started a week after I started tamoxifen and a couple of months after finishing chemo, but I don't know whether it's linked to either or just random. I mentioned it to my gp last week, and he said if it wasn't any better after a couple more weeks I should get it scanned just in case, and he was obviously thinking in case of mets, which threw me, as I hadn't thought of that, just thought tamoxifen or yet another docetaxel gift (still losing fingernails.) don't suppose any of you lovely ladies had anything similar?
Posts.Title: Hip pain - any ideas?

Posts.Content: When I had my lump removed in the summer, the sentinel node biopsy came back with 3/3 nodes cancerous. I'd gone in for my post surgery checkup expecting the all clear and suddenly was faced with chemo, more surgery and rads, plus the agonising wait for MRI/CT results to confirm it hadn't spread further. Just had my axillary clearance results - 10 more nodes removed, all clear. On the one hand, I guess the fewer nodes affected the better the prognosis, but on the other, I'm left feeling that the node clearance, which leaves me with a significant lifetime risk of lymphodema, wasn't actually necessary. I've always considered myself a real glass-half-full type, but some days it's really hard to focus on the bright side!
Posts.Title: Don't know whether to laugh or cry

Posts.Content: Just accept you have no way of knowing how it will affect you! It's so random, the best thing you can do is resign yourself to the uncertainty. Report any sickness and they'll give you better meds next time. Some effects are cumulative, so make the most of days when you feel well at the beginning as there could be fewer of them towards the end. And at the end, don't focus too much on looking forward to the last treatment - I did, and then got really fed up the following couple of weeks when I was still going though the side effects. Best tip though - if you've been trying to justify getting an ipad or similar, this is a brilliant excuse! I downloaded tv and radio programmes, puzzles, games and things to read .
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: I bet "bewildered" is just the tip of the emotion iceberg. Maybe it's the time of year, but I'm having a major wobble today. Finished my chemo last week and should be glad, but now all I can think about is the lymph node clearance (January), rads, and then tamoxifen - it seems to go on forever and with no guarantees. Like you I was total unsuspecting when I was diagnosed - I was 46, fit and healthy, no family history or other risk factors, no symptoms. Everyone thinks I'm coping well, but I'm angry and scared and lonely - I too don't want to worry my partner even more, I'm sure he's in denial about the fact that even all this treatment might not work. People think I'm a bit of a control freak, and suddenly all I can do is turn up at hospital and have them put stuff in me or take stuff out of me and there's nothing I can do to help myself. Sorry - I know I'm not helping, just feeling sorry for myself! You're still in the first phase of shock - be kinder to yourself! The next year will be a roller coaster. Once I started chemo I actually felt ok as it wasn't as grim as I'd feared. A week after the first dose I felt better than normal! I joked about gaining superpowers from the chemical enhancement. I think it's these times in between treatment which are worst, when all you can do is wait and worry. But I guess what we all find from going through this is we're stronger than we think. You'll pull through!
Posts.Title: Feeling bewildered

Posts.Content: I know exactly what you mean, Yasmin - I was so psyched about finishing chemo I got it doesn't finish on the last poisoning, but when the effects have worn off. The fortnight after the last dose was among the hardest time of the whole experience, because I just wanted to stop feeling rubbish, but I was at the lowest point physically. Dig in - you really are nearly there.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer triple neg grad 3

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne - I had exactly the same happen to me. Once I'd had the surgery the flushes went away, and it was just anxiety.
Posts.Title: Hot flushers

Posts.Content: My surgeon warned me it could take a year! It's only needed for an hour or so, you'd think they could develop something that was less stubborn! Though I guess that's not the top priority for cancer research... At least they waited for me to be unconscious before they injected it, unlike the radioactive injection - wow, that stung!
Posts.Title: The blue dye used in the Sentinel Lymph Node Bisopsy

Posts.Content: 4 months post chemo: fingernails almost back, toenails still falling off. Hair style now looks like a plausible fashion choice rather than a side effect, but I've also grown silky sideburns! Thank heavens for the Internet, so I could check others have also benefitted from the "blonde monkey" look, and that it goes away again after a few weeks. In the meantime I'm shaving! Chemo: just a bundle of of little treats.
Posts.Title: And now I've got sideburns!

Posts.Content: Hi - hope you're recovering well from the op. The waiting for the path results was one of the worst bits for me, and I ended up having no real choice about having the kitchen sink flung at me. You need to have a really good conversation with the oncologist. They have a predictor tool that works out what the added benefit of each treatment is for your diagnosis, and if the cancer hasn't spread to your nodes, I think the benefit of chemo is minimal. I was like you, ok about losing my hair (and actually, some days on chemo being able to shower and go straight back to bed without all that tedious hair drying is as good as it gets), but there's a whole load more potential side effects, some of which could continue affecting you for years, if not ever. I'm not trying to scare you, just to say - make sure you inform yourself of all the risks so you can balance them against the benefits. I genuinely don't know what choice I would have made, now I've gone through chemo, if I had thought it would only increase my chances by 1or 2%. Haven't started rads yet, so can't comment on how that makes you feel. Good luck, and stay strong.
Posts.Title: Had WLE and SLNB on Thursday 27th. Get pathology results on 11th March...

Posts.Content: Not hurtful, but definitely missing the point: I mentioned to a friend that I was getting close to the point when I would swop a ginger bob ( the rather jaunty wig I've worn for the duration) for a grey crop, and she replied "that's a move nobody wants to make". But I can't wait!
Posts.Title: Most outrageous, ridiculous etc
